Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 03:56PM madpeacock wrote: stjude10 - Know what you mean! My birthday is in a couple of weeks and people keep asking what I want. "No chemo!" Stuff is just stuff after all. My 86-yo mother in law, who lives with us for major health reasons, keeps telling me all the things she is going to do for me while I'm "unable". Uh, thanks, but that may cause more work than help... Really restless today waiting for the onc appt tomorrow. REALLY need to go run, but the knees need a day off and radar shows rain right around the corner - literally.

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 03:08PM madpeacock wrote: Mine was one week ago today. I'm wondering the same thing, though today it is a little better. I had impressive swelling and had it checked out at postop yesterday. They suggested heat, in the form of a hot washcloth or heating pad. The washcloth was just messy, though it felt good. The heating pad I folded in half and tucked it under my arm. That way the chest and arm both felt warm and relaxed and I really believe my swelling and weird tingly feelings have subsided a bit.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy recovery Yumaira cycle-path

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 05:14PM madpeacock wrote: I iced extensively after my biopsy, but only did a little after the lumpectomy. I wish I had done more but my DH was worried about moisture, etc. so by the time I padded up enough to satisfy him, I couldn't feel any benefit from the cold. Now a week later they are saying heat as I have fluid identified on ultrasound - either seroma or hematoma - and heat is supposed to help it be more mobile and resorb. My lump incision and SNB incision are very close to each other and the PA said there was no room for drainage.  I teach water aerobics - a very physical class - and I am out of that for a few weeks, at least. My arm feels tingly and numb though my range of motion is good. My incisions are sensitive today after all the bandages came off yesterday. I have been power walking since 3 days after surgery - I'm type A when it comes to exercise - but wonder if I overdid with arm motion, etc.  I only had 4 nodes removed, so I'm hoping lymphedema will not be an issue.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy recovery Yumaira cycle-path

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 06:26AM madpeacock wrote: I think everyone cringes when their area is misrepresented on TV. A tornado can rip a 50-mile swath through Georgia, but who do we interview on TV? The goober in the trailer with no teeth. Every time. On national news.  My husband is from rural west Georgia very close to the GA/AL line. We went back for a funeral this week. This is a Southern thing but when the funeral procession passes, you pull over to the side of the road in respect until all the cars pass. I grew up here, so took it for granted that it was done everywhere, but not the case. I came up on a funeral procession on the interstate in Atlanta one time and it felt weird NOT to pull over. The procession was going slower - about 50 MPH - and NOBODY would pass it and zoom on. It was like a rolling road block until they exited off the highway.
Posts.Title: OT - Regional Ways of Speaking redwolf8812 HLB

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 02:47PM madpeacock wrote: Georgia here, all my life. And I have NO accent of any sort. I have a voice for broadcast, LOL. My father was from Bronx/Long Island and my mother from South Carolina. He had a typical accent and my mother has just a soft southern hint.  Bad news of any sort here will earn you a well-meaning, "bless your heart".  "I got caught in the rain." "Bless your heart, go get dried off." " I have breast cancer." (Shocked face, shaking head) "Bless your heart!" (Got this one MANY times...) Guess it is better than some of the stupid things people say....
Posts.Title: OT - Regional Ways of Speaking redwolf8812 HLB

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 03:38PM madpeacock wrote: I'm missing the pool! I teach (and take) water aerobics and I haven't been given a definite timeframe of how long that I cannot be in the water. I had a lumpectomy a week ago today and looking at the incisions I would not want to subject it to pool water for a while yet. I have arranged subs for three weeks, but may have to extend that.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 06:53PM - edited Sep 8, 2011 06:54PM by madpeacock Hi everyone - My surgery went very well! The sentinel node biopsy was easy-peasy and came back NEGATIVE! I was home by 10:30 a.m. and have been hanging out and had a nap. The anesthesiologist gave me a patch behind my ear to ward off nausea because I almost always barf after anesthesia, and so far - it works! Wonder if one could use these for chemo nausea instead of yet another pill?? The worst part - and is really only annoying - is the chest binder they put me in to keep everything compressed. Doesn't fit me quite right so it keeps slipping down from the incision areas. I'm pretty thin through the middle, so maybe it is made to rest on fuller figures. Regardless, tug, tug, pull, pull.   Hope you all rest well tonight and heal quickly!

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2012 10:38AM madpeacock wrote: Thank you for the opportunity to ask my question in this forum. Concerning bone mets - is there any tendency for a metastasis to go to an OLD fracture site? I had a stress fracture in my left femur about seven years ago from running (had plantar fascitis at the time and was unconciously turning my foot out to avoid the painful spot, thus torquing the femur...and...crack).  I'm a little over one year out from stage IC IDC. Was HER2+ on biopsy, but onc retested it TWICE because it didn't "fit the rest of my picture" and it came back negative both times. We even discussed at my most recent appointment that maybe the biopsy got the one bit that was HER2+. Mentally, I packed up all the worry and stowed it away in long term storage. I'm not a worrier/anxious at all, so once treatment was over, I was done and ready to get back to life.  Recently, however, the left femur has started to hurt. I remember the bone pain when it was broken - not an easy thing to forget - and this is bone pain. SO different from muscle pain/strain. Not nearly as bad as then, but pain. I am active - I run, cycle, and teach an aerobics class - but nothing to excess. Maybe it is my 50 yo body telling me that I'm not as young as I used to be, but now I have to wonder if something else is going on.  So, long question short, would an old fracture have a higher risk of mets, being a so-called "weak" spot?  Again, thank you for your thoughts.

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 11:09AM madpeacock wrote: I had a breast MRI done before surgery but no PET or CT. I have bloodwork and TMs done at the MO and diagnostic mammos every six months.  NancyHB - my basic stats were very similar to yours, but my Oncotype was only 8! As I keep hearing over and over, each person's BC is unique and no one will have the same path as someone else with basically the same stats. One person may have a high grade, stage III tumor and never recur, and someone with DCIS may end up with mets.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 10:08AM madpeacock wrote: Sheila - will definitely be in your pocket!! I guess I'm the opposite of anxious - it takes a lot to get me upset/anxious/mad/nervous. My MIL lives with us and she is extremely fatalistic - always anticipates the worst that could happen in any situation. I had a good MO checkup recently and my husband told her and her comment was "Are you telling me the truth? She's not hiding something from me?" Sheesh. When our daughter was very small (and my MIL still lived by herself) she would call and if we weren't home she would leave a message and say, "Well, I hope you're not at the hospital with the baby." Uh, no.  Just out living our lives.  Hi Valerie! Sounds like you do have a lot going on. I went through genetic testing also since there is no history of BC in my family on either side. However, my father's side are Ashkenazi Jews, so they were worried about the connection coming from that. Thankfully I was BRCA negative. I would have had the same recommendation of BMX and hysterectomy. Sounds like your MO is a lot like mine - wants to make sure all the bases are covered before just slapping a generic treatment course on you. Mine also retested my HER2 - which was positive on biopsy - because she didn't think it "fit" the rest of my picture and it came back negative TWICE - so my treatment course was altered significantly.  Thank God too for good docs!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker
